channel.title: [SOLVED] Optical Bot question - How to grab BufferedImage from applet
channel.description: Hey Everybody! =D I started a new optical bot porject 1 month ago (YES, i know i could just use reflection or some other method, but i wanted to challenge myself :)), and i recently even got the OCR working =D(22ms average per line of text). Everything is ready to start making the scripter's API now, but i am having an issue. How am I to get the BufferedImage from the RS applet? Let's start with this information: I have in the class GUI.class a public static Applet. Is there a method that i could grab the image of the applet even when the bot is minimized? Also, how am I going to get mouse/key events working without having to use robot (without using cherokee engine)? Thanks! =D

item.title: [SOLVED] Optical Bot question - How to grab BufferedImage from applet
item.dc:creator: @Entropy Entropy
item.description:
@Entropy wrote:

solved

item.title: [SOLVED] Optical Bot question - How to grab BufferedImage from applet
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

[quote=“Speljohan, post:60, topic:404009”][quote author=slavemaster link=topic=501068.msg3699206#msg3699206 date=1312642551]
What about higher-level events for scripters? I’m sure nobody would like to deal with interpreting events like AnimationEvent and filtering them by ID manually… I’d like to think internals as such should be hidden from the eyes of the scripter, and they should be given a much prettier, abstract facade.

An average scripter should not be meant to understand much of the client’s nor your own system’s internals, it may be a bit too much for them. :rolleyes:
[/quote]We accomplished that a slighly hackish way by having the raw events sent to bot, then had them filtered using reflection, so basically you declared a given event in the script and it would be used accordingly.

Probably a bad description, but here’s how it looks: http://pastebin.com/G5tQUFdX

Yes, it’s ugly shit, but it worked![/quote]

That’s quite a few interfaces it implements

Read full topic

@Ollie wrote:

slavemaster:

That’s not very precise, is it, Ollie? Can you be assured the only java.awt.Canvas created in the lifespan of the JVM belongs to RuneScape’s codebase?

If we are loading the runescape applet then yes, any canvas created will belong to runescapes codebase… this is also using the unsigned or the signed applet.

item.title: [SOLVED] Optical Bot question - How to grab BufferedImage from applet
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

Despite the apparent “inaccuracy”, I have never had a problem with what Ollie said.

Simply override the Canvas class with your own, -Xbootclasspath the jar and I put a call in the constructor of the Canvas class similar to: “Bot.resetGraphics()”.

It is true that they do generate different Canvas’ throughout the game, but it isn’t as random as people believe. A new one is generated when the login form appears, on login(?), and whenever you change the state of the window (minimized/maximized). On the unsigned client, the canvas also updates (sometimes) when you change regions.

Its true this method could be beaten, but that alone does not make it inaccurate. At the time of posting, it works perfectly fine.

Read full topic
item.source: [SOLVED] Optical Bot question - How to grab BufferedImage from applet

item.title: [SOLVED] Optical Bot question - How to grab BufferedImage from applet
item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

Entropy:

yes but i want to use reflection, not injection

Have fun polling! … I kid
While not strictly a reflection-driven solution, you should look into JDI API. If you identify the java.awt.Canvas field successfully, you can listen for mutations in the value via ModificationWatchpointRequests. Find the appropriate Field (com.sun.jdi, not java.lang.reflect) and pass it to EventRequestManager.createModificationWatchpointRequest() and then enable() it. Note that the virtual machine you’re inspecting here must support watching for modifications i.e. VirtualMachine.canWatchFieldModification().

If you need an EventRequestManager just query your VirtualMachine via eventRequestManager().

Read full topic

[/quote]

I suspected so… I was just wondering if you knew of any explicitly. Either way, a reactive system for botting in general is a few steps forward than any bots currently available. Even Aryan and ARGA were more event-driven than say PowerBot, weren’t they? Say, whatever happened to GeneriBot? :rolleyes:[/quote]Zetabot was pretty much exclusively event-driven too. Could do most things in the game with just 11 callbacks

item.dc:creator: @slavemaster veer
item.description:
@slavemaster wrote:

Maybe I have some weird affinity towards dealing with the game codebase directly but I don’t feel right about firing from java.awt.Canvas’ constructor. You brought up that the desired Canvas has specific properties; however, what properties? As far as I know it is just a plain old java.awt.Canvas created by code akin to

Read full topic
item.source: [SOLVED] Optical Bot question - How to grab BufferedImage from applet

item.title: [SOLVED] Optical Bot question - How to grab BufferedImage from applet
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

[quote=“slavemaster, post:46, topic:404009”]That’s not very precise, is it, Ollie? Can you be assured the only java.awt.Canvas created in the lifespan of the JVM belongs to RuneScape’s codebase?
I’d like to think most people /avoid/ risk and prefer easier implementation and would do it the cleaner, more direct way, by hacking the client itself at update checkpoints. You ought to have already analysed the code to find out that it does it at all, so it can’t be much harder to locate just exactly where it does it, too… right?[/quote]

Not very hard at all. You can take a fairly naive approach towards it as well I suppose. Injecting a callback at a dummy/unused instantiation won’t have any negative effects. The only issue with injecting at every NEW <java/awt/Canvas> would be if they make the actual Canvas and then a junk one shortly after so you end up holding onto the junk one. However, it still isn’t much of a problem to solve.

Actually, injecting into the Canvas constructor(s) might not be that bad of a solution. I’d guess that the Canvas that ends up getting used has some specific properties; creation time would probably be pretty useful too.

Read full topic
